{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3426520,"name":"Ardiano Works","username":"MSU2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msu2000/{size}/190139_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-23T22:23:18.441Z","cooked":"

Say for Crescendo, I’m curious how do you guys determine where you mount your flywheel for shooter mechanism. Assuming you settle on the RPM, surface speed, Dia, Inertia, time to reach the speed, etc, basically specking the gear ratio and the motor.

  1. Is it better to mount the flywheel closer to the note shooter roller or do you mount the flywheel closer to the motor. Why?
  2. Is it better to have flywheel connected to belt drive or gear?
  3. How do you balance the flywheel?

Thanks

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2024-09-23T22:23:18.441Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":40,"reads":199,"readers_count":198,"score":274.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":471735,"topic_slug":"flywheel-location-for-shooter-mechanism","display_username":"Ardiano Works","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57747,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/flywheel-location-for-shooter-mechanism/471735/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3426532,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-23T23:06:59.650Z","cooked":"

There’s two main tactics: use the flywheel AS the shooting roller, and an auxiliary flywheel. If you have a separate flywheel, you can spin it faster and its size isn’t dictated by the needs of the shooting mechanism. Plus the drive allows you more flexibility on where it goes.

I see more belt drives on flywheel type shooters than gears. Likely quieter.

I think most teams don’t balance flywheels, but that’s my guess. Symmetry and “bought it that way”… Its tricky to get them onto a Nies balancer or prop balancer if you’ve got a hex shaft in there; they are kinda sloppy. Shim it or loctite it to fix that.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2024-09-23T23:06:59.650Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":185,"readers_count":184,"score":57.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":471735,"topic_slug":"flywheel-location-for-shooter-mechanism","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/flywheel-location-for-shooter-mechanism/471735/2","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3426588,"name":"Domtech","username":"Domtech","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/domtech/{size}/138487_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-24T02:45:45.589Z","cooked":"
MSU2000:

Is it better to mount the flywheel closer to the note shooter roller or do you mount the flywheel closer to the motor. Why?

Better in what way? The inertia of the system should be tuned to your needs and more inertia isn’t always “better”. A launcher that only fires one game piece and spins down between shots does not need much inertia.

In the case of a heavy game piece, giving the roller extra inertia directly can reduce shock-loading to belts/gears/chain driving it.

Flywheels will have more effect the higher they are geared relative to the roller. If your roller is geared slower than your motor, then a flywheel will have more effect connected to the motor. If your roller is geared faster than you motor, then it would have the most effect if it is part of the roller shaft. If you require a lot of inertia in you system then you could have the flywheel geared at a faster speed than either the roller or the motor, but that is generally extra complexity for a small weigh saving vs just putting a slightly larger flywheel on the existing roller shaft.

Moment of inertia is also important to consider. A flywheel with a larger diameter has more effect for the same weight than a smaller solid wheel.

ReCalc is a great resource for simulating how different gear ratios and inertias will affect your launcher.

MSU2000:

Is it better to have flywheel connected to belt drive or gear?

The elasticity of belts provides a little bit of shock absorption, and they tend to be much quieter. Belts and chain spread load over multiple teeth so they should wear less than gears. They also provide more flexibility in positioning and tend to be much lighter than gears for runs over long distance. It’s easier to change directions with gears though if multiple rollers are needed spinning opposite directions.

None of them are a bad option and generally the choice comes down more to what you have the most experience working with.

MSU2000:

How do you balance the flywheel?

Most teams don’t bother more than throwing out wheels that are noticeably out of balance and checking that you use very straight axle stock.
